study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the effects and mechanisms of α-KG on alveolar macrophage polarization and its potential therapeutic role in LPS-induced ALI/ARDS.
results_summary: α-KG inhibited M1 macrophage polarization and promoted M2 polarization in MH-S cells by modulating mTORC1/p70S6K signaling and PPARγ nuclear translocation. In mice, α-KG reduced LPS-induced inflammation and lung damage, improving clinical scores.
population_specificity: Murine alveolar macrophage cell line (MH-S) and LPS-induced ALI/ARDS mouse model.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether Empagliflozin (EMPA) has acute metabolic effects on glucose and fatty acid metabolism in isolated diabetic hearts, specifically focusing on lactate and α-ketoglutarate (α-KG) production.
results_summary: EMPA increased cardiac labeling in α-ketoglutarate derived from 13C palmitate perfusions (86 ± 1% vs. 79 ± 1% for vehicle; P = 0.01) but had no overall acute effect on glucose or fatty acid metabolism. The study also found that EMPA's effect on lactate labeling was mediated through NHE-1 inhibition.
population_specificity: Type II diabetic db/db mouse hearts
interactions: NHE-1 inhibitor (Cariporide) nullified EMPA's effects on lactate labeling.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the protective effects and mechanisms of ornithine α-ketoglutarate (OKG) against d-galactose-induced chronic oxidative stress in pigs.
results_summary: OKG (0.5%) improved growth performance, enhanced antioxidant enzyme levels (SOD, GSH-Px), reduced lipid oxidation (MDA), modulated gut microbiota, and restored serum amino acid levels in pigs exposed to oxidative stress. Higher doses (1%, 2%) were not as effective as 0.5% OKG.
population_specificity: Castrated young pigs (n=40).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the role of intracellular α-ketoglutarate in hepatic stellate cell (HSC) activation and its mechanism of action in liver fibrosis.
results_summary: The study found that intracellular α-ketoglutarate levels decreased during HSC activation, and knockdown of IDH2 (an enzyme producing α-ketoglutarate) promoted HSC activation, which was reversible with an α-ketoglutarate analogue. The effect was independent of TGF-β1.
population_specificity: Human HSC cell line (LX-2) and primary mouse HSCs.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the effects of pyruvate and dimethyl α-ketoglutarate (dm-α-KG) on blastocyst formation rates and post-implantation developmental ability in ICR mouse zygotes.
results_summary: dm-α-KG significantly improved blastocyst formation rates (from 12% to 49%) when combined with low pyruvate (0.01 mmol/L) and enhanced birth rates (31.0% vs. 16.3%) when combined with higher pyruvate (0.2 mmol/L). Pyruvate and dm-α-KG showed synergistic effects in improving embryo development.
population_specificity: ICR mouse zygotes

study_goal: The researchers aimed to develop an efficient and cost-effective method to separate α-ketoglutaric acid (KGA) from pyruvic acid (PYR) in fermentation broth using biological pathways.
results_summary: The study established a separation process converting PYR to l-tyrosine (TYR), which was easily precipitated and removed, yielding high-purity KGA (98.16%) and TYR (98.19%) with recovery rates of 78.68% and 73.46%, respectively. The method simplified separation and reduced operational costs.
population_specificity: Fermentation broth from Yarrowia lipolytica WSH-Z06.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess the potential protective effects of α-ketoglutarate against colorectal cancer (CRC) development, focusing on its anti-inflammatory and antitumour properties.
results_summary: α-Ketoglutarate significantly protected against CRC development in mice, reduced pro-inflammatory cytokines (IL-6, IL-22, TNF-α, IL-1β), and modulated gut microbiota by decreasing opportunistic pathogens while increasing beneficial bacteria.
population_specificity: C57BL/6 mice with induced CRC using azoxymethane (AOM) and dextran sulfate sodium (DSS).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the protective efficacy of alpha-ketoglutarate (AKG) combined with N-acetyl cysteine (NAC) against chronic cyanide toxicity in rats, focusing on oxidative stress, inflammation, and histological changes.
results_summary: The study found that AKG + NAC co-treatment reduced oxidative stress, neuroinflammation, and histological damage caused by chronic cyanide exposure, with no reported detrimental effects from either compound alone.
population_specificity: Rats exposed to subchronic cyanide toxicity.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the effects of α-Ketoglutarate (α-KG) on preimplantation embryo development, including blastocyst rate, inner cell mass (ICM) cell count, and fetal growth post-embryo transfer.
results_summary: α-KG (150 μM) significantly improved blastocyst rate, ICM cell number, and fetal growth. It modulated mitochondrial function to preserve pluripotency and altered epigenetic markers (5hmC/5mC ratio) to enhance embryo adaptation to in vitro conditions.
population_specificity: Preimplantation embryos (in vitro study).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the hepatoprotective potential of oral alpha-ketoglutarate (AKG) supplementation against alcohol-induced hepatic dysfunction using biochemical, histopathological, and functional imaging approaches.
results_summary: AKG supplementation significantly improved liver function in ethanol-treated animals, as evidenced by enhanced hepatic extraction fraction, faster radiotracer clearance, and improved biochemical and histopathological markers compared to the ethanol-only group. The results suggest AKG has a protective effect against alcohol-induced liver injury.
population_specificity: Animal model (rats, n=6 per group)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether Alpha-Ketoglutarate (AKG) protects against oxidative stress by activating the CAR signaling pathway and modulating antioxidant-related targets in porcine intestinal cells and piglets.
results_summary: AKG supplementation significantly increased AKG and related metabolite levels, reduced ROS levels, enhanced antioxidant enzyme activities, improved cellular respiration, and regulated key antioxidant and detoxification genes. It also modulated protein levels of SOD1, SOD2, CAR, RXRα, UCP2, Nrf2, and Keap1, suggesting protective effects against oxidative stress.
population_specificity: Porcine intestinal cells and piglets exposed to H2O2.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the anti-metastatic effects of AA6, an α-ketoglutarate dehydrogenase inhibitor, and its impact on α-KG accumulation and epigenetic regulation in breast cancer models.
results_summary: AA6 treatment led to α-KG accumulation, increased TET enzyme activity, and upregulated anti-metastatic miRNA 200 family, resulting in reduced metastasis formation and impaired tumor aggressiveness in mice. The study also noted enhanced nitric oxide production and inhibition of epithelial-to-mesenchymal transition.
population_specificity: Orthotopic mouse model of breast cancer (4T1) and human breast cancer cell lines.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the role of IDH2 and α-Ketoglutarate in LPS-induced acute lung injury (ALI) and whether disrupting IDH2 could reduce inflammation and lung injury.
results_summary: The study found that IDH2 deficiency reduced α-KG levels, attenuated LPS-induced inflammation and lung injury, and suppressed proinflammatory cytokine production by inhibiting the NF-κB signaling pathway, leading to improved survival in mice.
population_specificity: IDH2-deficient mice exposed to LPS-induced ALI.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the effects of dietary Alpha-Ketoglutarate (AKG) combined with allicin on intestinal microbiota composition, diversity, and volatile fatty acid metabolism in growing pigs.
results_summary: The combination of AKG and allicin improved cecal microbial diversity, increased Firmicutes and Prevotella abundance, reduced Bacteroidetes, and enhanced butyrate and total volatile fatty acid levels compared to control and antibiotic groups.
population_specificity: Growing pigs

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the effects of dietary Alpha-Ketoglutarate (AKG) supplementation on the intestinal immune system and PXR-regulated target expression in LPS-challenged piglets and intestinal porcine epithelial cells.
results_summary: AKG supplementation reversed LPS-induced adverse effects, inhibited the NF-κB-mediated inflammatory pathway, suppressed TNF-α, and upregulated PXR and its downstream targets, suggesting improved intestinal immune function.
population_specificity: Piglets and intestinal porcine epithelial cells (IPEC-J2).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the role of α-ketoglutarate in regulating extracellular vesicle (EV) release during HIV-1 infection and immune activation.
results_summary: The study found that α-ketoglutarate, produced via GLS1-mediated glutaminolysis, is critical for EV release in HIV-1-infected macrophages and immune-activated microglia. Supplementation with α-ketoglutarate rescued EV release when GLS1 was inhibited.
population_specificity: Human monocyte-derived macrophages, BV2 microglia cell line, and GLS1-transgenic mice.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether alpha-ketoglutarate (αKG) could suppress breast cancer metastasis by modulating metabolic pathways and enhancing tumor suppressor activity.
results_summary: The study found that αKG supplementation reduced oncometabolites (succinate and fumarate), stabilized HIF prolyl hydroxylase 2 (PHD2), decreased HIF1α, and shifted glucose metabolism from glycolysis to oxidative phosphorylation, ultimately suppressing breast cancer metastasis. Combining αKG with TKT inhibition enhanced cell death in triple-negative breast cancer (TNBC) cells.
population_specificity: Breast cancer models (4T1/BALB/c syngeneic model and TNBC cells) and patient samples with lymph node metastases.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the effects of dietary Alpha-Ketoglutarate (AKG) supplementation on epithelial restitution and intestinal inflammatory response in early-weaning piglets under LPS-induced stress.
results_summary: AKG supplementation improved growth performance, intestinal morphology, and nutrient-sensing transporter expression while reducing inflammatory cytokines and enhancing tight-junction protein distribution in LPS-induced piglets.
population_specificity: Early-weaning piglets

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess the impact of AKG on osteogenesis in vitro and identify the signaling mechanisms involved in its activity.
results_summary: AKG did not increase osteoblast proliferation but upregulated markers of osteoblast differentiation and mineralization, activating the JNK and mTOR/S6K1/S6 pathways independently of GPR99.
population_specificity: Human (hFOB 1.19) and mouse (MC3T3-E1) osteoblast cell lines.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine how melatonin increases α-ketoglutarate (αKG) levels in adipose tissue and its role in alleviating metabolic inflammation in obesity.
results_summary: Melatonin elevated αKG levels in adipose tissue, reduced inflammation, and improved macrophage polarization by increasing exosomal αKG transport and promoting DNA demethylation. αKG also inhibited STAT3/NF-κB signaling via OXGR1, further reducing inflammation.
population_specificity: Obese mice and chronic jet-lag mice.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether Alpha-Ketoglutarate (AKG) could prevent skeletal muscle protein degradation and atrophy through the PHD3/ADRB2 pathway.
results_summary: AKG effectively attenuated corticosterone-induced protein degradation, rescued muscle atrophy and dysfunction in a Duchenne muscular dystrophy mouse model, and inhibited PHD3 expression, stabilizing ADRB2. The findings suggest AKG's potential in treating muscle atrophy via the PHD3/ADRB2 mechanism.
population_specificity: Duchenne muscular dystrophy mouse model

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine if exogenous alpha-ketoglutarate (AKG) could protect baker's yeast (Saccharomyces cerevisiae) against freeze-thaw and carbohydrate-induced stresses, improving viability and fermentative capacity.
results_summary: AKG supplementation improved yeast cell viability, fermentative capacity, metabolic activity, and antioxidant capacity after freeze-thaw stress. It also prevented carbohydrate-induced cell death by enhancing respiration and maintaining protein levels.
population_specificity: Saccharomyces cerevisiae (baker's yeast)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether dietary Alpha-Ketoglutarate (AKG) improves intestinal water and ion homeostasis in LPS-challenged piglets and whether the AMPK pathway is involved.
results_summary: AKG supplementation reduced diarrhea incidence, reversed serum parameter imbalances, upregulated intestinal aquaporins, and enhanced AMPK pathway protein expression in LPS-challenged piglets.
population_specificity: Weaned piglets

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare nanosizing techniques (milling and precipitation) for alpha-ketoglutarate as a dry powder inhaler to treat cyanide poisoning, focusing on particle characteristics and lung deposition.
results_summary: Probe sonication with Pluronic F68 produced well-stabilized small particles with 43.13% lung deposition, outperforming ultrasonication (31.69%) and precipitation (21.67%). Phase-I trials showed 52.51% whole lung deposition, with uniform particle distribution (P/C ratio 1.02).
population_specificity: Not specified (Phase-I trial implies human subjects, but details are lacking).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the impact of alpha-ketoglutarate accumulation on stromal precursor cell differentiation and its role in mitochondrial dysfunction-related aging disorders.
results_summary: The study found that alpha-ketoglutarate accumulation in Sod2-deficient and aged stromal precursor cells impaired differentiation, leading to cell death via DNA damage, Hif-1α instability, and reduced histone acetylation. These metabolic disruptions suggest a potential therapeutic target for aging-related mitochondrial disorders.
population_specificity: Stromal precursor cells (in vitro study)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the hepatoprotective role of Alpha-Ketoglutarate (α-KG) in acetaminophen (APAP)-induced liver toxicity in rats.
results_summary: The study found that α-KG significantly reduced liver damage markers (ALT, AST, ALP, MDA) and restored antioxidant levels (GSH, SOD, CAT) in APAP-treated rats. Histological analysis confirmed reduced inflammation and necrosis with α-KG co-administration.
population_specificity: Rats (animal study)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether dietary alpha-ketoglutarate (AKG) could protect against ethanol toxicity and improve physiological outcomes in Drosophila melanogaster.
results_summary: AKG supplementation alleviated ethanol toxicity, improved fly development, increased alcohol dehydrogenase (ADH) activity, and enhanced some antioxidant defenses, suggesting protective effects against ethanol-induced harm.
population_specificity: Fruit flies (Drosophila melanogaster)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether dimethyl α-ketoglutarate (DMKG) could inhibit hepatic stellate cell (HSC) activation and autophagy, thereby preventing liver fibrosis.
results_summary: DMKG reduced CCl4-induced liver fibrosis in Wistar rats and inhibited HSC autophagy and activation in vitro, leading to lipid droplet accumulation and decreased ATP content. The anti-fibrotic effect involved acetyl-coenzyme A and EP300 pathways.
population_specificity: Wistar rats and HSC-T6 cell lines.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to explore the role of α-ketoglutarate (αKG) in the metabolic alterations of IDH-mutant and IDH-wt gliomas, identifying potential therapeutic vulnerabilities.
results_summary: The study highlights αKG's central role in glioma energy and lipid metabolism, suggesting it as a key metabolite influencing tumor biology and indicating possible therapeutic targets for both IDH-mutant and IDH-wt gliomas.
population_specificity: Glioblastoma multiforme (GBM) and lower-grade gliomas, specifically IDH-mutant and IDH-wt gliomas.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether AMPK activation, through its influence on α-ketoglutarate (αKG) levels, plays a role in brown adipose tissue (BAT) development and thermogenesis.
results_summary: The study found that AMPKα1 ablation reduced αKG levels and impaired BAT development, while AMPK activation with AICAR or metformin rescued obesity-induced suppression of brown adipogenesis and thermogenesis, linking αKG to progenitor cell differentiation.
population_specificity: The study focused on mechanisms in early brown adipogenesis, likely using animal or cellular models (specific population not detailed in the abstract).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine how Psat1 regulates α-ketoglutarate (α-KG) levels and influences the fate of mouse embryonic stem cells (mESCs) during differentiation.
results_summary: The study found that Psat1 maintains intracellular α-KG levels, which are crucial for mESC self-renewal and pluripotency. Moderate knockdown of Psat1 reduced α-KG, altered epigenetic markers, and accelerated differentiation, while dysregulation of α-KG impeded differentiation.
population_specificity: Mouse embryonic stem cells (mESCs)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to review the metabolic and extrametabolic functions of Alpha-Ketoglutarate (AKG), its therapeutic potential in various diseases, and its roles as an immunomodulatory agent and bone anabolic factor.
results_summary: The study found that AKG plays multiple roles in metabolic and cellular pathways, including energy donation, amino acid biosynthesis, and regulation of epigenetic processes. It also demonstrated potential therapeutic applications in protein deficiency, oxidative stress, immunomodulation, bone health, and cancer.
population_specificity: Not specified (review of existing studies).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the effects of alpha-ketoglutarate (AKG) and ipriflavone (IP) on tibia mineralization during osteopenia development and after its establishment in male rats.
results_summary: AKG and IP, when used alone, counteracted osteopenia development, and their combined use after osteopenia establishment significantly limited bone disorders. AKG and IP also inhibited bone resorption and stimulated bone tissue formation during osteopenia development.
population_specificity: Male rats (sham-operated or orchidectomized)
effective_dosage: AKG at 1.0 mol/l in drinking water; IP at 50 mg/kg body weight daily via gavage

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether Alpha-Ketoglutarate modulates pro-inflammatory cytokine levels and toll-like receptor 4 expression in patients with non-alcoholic fatty liver disease.
results_summary: Alpha-Ketoglutarate did not modulate cytokine levels or toll-like receptor 4 expression in non-alcoholic fatty liver disease patients, showing no significant effect.
population_specificity: Obese and lean patients with non-alcoholic fatty liver disease, with or without metabolic syndrome, and varying glucose tolerance (prediabetes or normoglycemia).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effects of Alpha-Ketoglutarate (AKG) on glutamine metabolism in piglets and intestinal epithelial cells, comparing its efficacy to L-glutamine supplementation.
results_summary: AKG supplementation improved average daily gain and feed efficiency in piglets, enhanced intestinal morphology, and increased amino acid transporter expression. In vitro, AKG reduced glutamine utilization and ammonia production in a dose-dependent manner.
population_specificity: Weaned piglets (28 days old, mean body weight 6.0 ± 0.2 kg) and intestinal porcine epithelial cells (IPEC-1).
effective_dosage: 1% AKG in diet (in vivo); 0.5, 2, and 3 mM AKG (in vitro).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to examine the effects of lithium on the renal organic anion transport system, including the role of α-ketoglutarate as a driving force for transporters rOAT1 and rOAT3.
results_summary: Lithium chloride dose-dependently interfered with renal excretion of phenolsulfonphthalein and significantly decreased α-ketoglutarate levels in the kidney cortex, suggesting dysfunction in the renal organic anion transport system. No changes were observed in rOAT1 and rOAT3 expression levels.
population_specificity: Rats
effective_dosage: Not specified (dose-dependent infusion of lithium chloride)
study_duration: Not specified (measurements taken until 60 minutes post-injection)
interactions: Lithium chloride interfered with renal excretion of phenolsulfonphthalein

study_goal: The researchers aimed to replicate key experiments demonstrating the competitive inhibition of α-ketoglutarate-dependent dioxygenases by the oncometabolite 2-hydroxyglutarate (2-HG).
results_summary: The study confirmed that mutant IDH1 increases 2-HG levels and that 2-HG treatment alters histone methylation, mimicking the effects of mutant IDH1.
population_specificity: In vitro and/or cell-based models (specific human population not detailed).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the role of the alpha-ketoglutarate dehydrogenase (Slα-kGDH) E2 subunit in salicylic acid (SA)-induced plant defense against tobacco mosaic virus (TMV).
results_summary: The study found that Slα-kGDH E2 binds SA and modulates plant resistance to TMV. Silencing Slα-kGDH E2 increased TMV resistance, while SA reduced TMV susceptibility in plants overexpressing Slα-kGDH E2, indicating its role in mitochondrial electron transport chain-mediated defense.
population_specificity: Tomato (Solanum lycopersicum) and Nicotiana benthamiana plants.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether α-ketoglutarate (α-KG) extends lifespan in Caenorhabditis elegans and to identify its molecular mechanisms of action.
results_summary: α-KG extended lifespan in C. elegans by inhibiting ATP synthase, reducing ATP content, decreasing oxygen consumption, and increasing autophagy. The lifespan increase was dependent on ATP synthase subunit β and TOR signaling, and α-KG did not further extend lifespan in dietary-restricted animals.
population_specificity: Adult Caenorhabditis elegans and mammalian cells.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the potential of α-ketoglutarate supplementation in preventing dysfunction of the intestinal epithelium.
results_summary: The study found that α-ketoglutarate exhibits bioactive effects such as antioxidant activity, epigenetic modification cofactor function, and anti-inflammatory properties, suggesting its potential in maintaining intestinal epithelial homeostasis.
population_specificity: Not specified (general focus on intestinal epithelium function).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to explore the impact of exogenous alpha-ketoglutarate supplementation on reproductive capabilities, focusing on its mechanisms and effects in animal models.
results_summary: Alpha-ketoglutarate supplementation induced dose- and sex-dependent modifications, improved oocyte quality and quantity, delayed reproductive aging, and mitigated oxidative stress, demonstrating a direct influence on reproductive performance and metabolic adjustments.
population_specificity: Animal models (specific species not detailed in the abstract).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to explore Alpha-Ketoglutarate's potential therapeutic applications in skeletal muscle health and exercise performance, focusing on muscle regeneration and atrophy prevention.
results_summary: AKG supports muscle recovery by stimulating muscle satellite cells and macrophage polarization, aids muscle repair, and reduces fibrosis. It also enhances protein synthesis, inhibits degradation pathways, and modulates inflammatory responses, showing promise in conditions like sarcopenia and cachexia, as well as improving endurance and recovery in athletes.
population_specificity: Athletes, active individuals, and those with conditions like sarcopenia and cachexia.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the cytotoxicity of native and TFE-treated alpha-lactalbumins from equine, bovine, and human milk.
results_summary: Native alpha-lactalbumins from all three sources were non-cytotoxic, but TFE-treated versions exhibited cytotoxicity, with equine α-LA being the most potent, bovine moderate, and human weak. No significant structural changes were observed between native and TFE-treated forms.
population_specificity: In vitro study (no human or animal subjects specified).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine if intravesical HAMLET (human alpha-lactalbumin made lethal to tumor cells) could selectively remove cancer cells in patients with nonmuscle invasive transitional cell carcinomas.
results_summary: HAMLET increased tumor cell shedding in urine, induced apoptosis in most patients, and reduced tumor size or altered tumor character in 8 of 9 patients, with no toxic effects on healthy tissue. The effect was specific to HAMLET, as control treatments did not produce similar outcomes.
population_specificity: Patients with nonmuscle invasive transitional cell carcinomas.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine if HAMLET-like complexes (tumoricidal alpha-lactalbumin and oleic acid) are present in casein from different species and if isolated alpha-lactalbumins from those species can form such complexes.
results_summary: Active HAMLET-like complexes were only found in human casein, but purified alpha-lactalbumins from bovine, equine, porcine, and caprine milk formed similar complexes with oleic acid. Natural HAMLET formation in casein was unique to human milk, which also had the highest oleic acid content.
population_specificity: Casein and alpha-lactalbumin from human, bovine, equine, porcine, and caprine milk.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to study the effect of heat treatment on the denaturation of alpha-lactalbumin under different conditions and temperatures.
results_summary: Alpha-lactalbumin was found to be more heat-sensitive in milk than in phosphate buffer, denatured faster in the apo form than in the calcium-saturated form, and showed decreased thermal stability when oleic acid was bound.
population_specificity: Not specified (in vitro study)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to study the effects of alkaline conditions on the decomposition of bovine alpha-lactalbumin, particularly focusing on peptide bond cleavage and disulfide degradation.
results_summary: Under alkaline conditions (pH 13), alpha-lactalbumin experienced peptide bond cleavage at asparaginyl residues when DTT was present, while disulfide bonds degraded in its absence. The study identified specific cleavage sites and reaction tendencies under these conditions.
population_specificity: Purified bovine alpha-lactalbumin (in vitro study)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the potential of using the alpha-lactalbumin promoter to control adenovirus replication for targeted gene therapy in breast cancer.
results_summary: The study found that alpha-lactalbumin promoter-driven adenoviruses (AdALAE1a and AdE1aALAE1b) effectively replicated and killed breast cancer cells (MDA-MB-435S and T47D) while showing attenuated effects in non-breast cancer cells. AdE1aALAE1b demonstrated superior breast cancer-restricted replication and inhibited tumor growth in vivo.
population_specificity: Breast cancer cell lines (MDA-MB-435S and T47D) and normal breast cell lines.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the structural changes and copolymer formation of Alpha-Lactalbumin under high pressure and temperature treatments in raw skim milk.
results_summary: Alpha-Lactalbumin formed copolymers mainly with kappa-casein and beta-lactoglobulin via intermolecular disulfide bond exchange, with a proportion of 0.7 relative to beta-lactoglobulin. The copolymers had apparent molecular masses ranging from 440 to over 2000 kDa.
population_specificity: Raw skim milk samples

study_goal: The researchers aimed to examine the effects of high pressure-induced denaturation on alpha-lactalbumin in dairy systems, comparing its baroresistance in milk and whey.
results_summary: Alpha-lactalbumin was more baroresistant than beta-lactoglobulin, with higher denaturation in milk than whey. Denaturation was influenced by sulphydryl-disulphide interchange reactions and the presence of colloidal calcium phosphate.
population_specificity: Not specified (in vitro study on dairy systems)
interactions: Sulphydryl-oxidising agent (KlO3) increased beta-lactoglobulin denaturation but reduced alpha-lactalbumin denaturation; sulphydryl-blocking agent (N-ethylmaleimide) prevented denaturation of both proteins.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether topical alpha-lactalbumin-oleic acid (HAMLET) selectively kills transformed cells (skin papillomas) while sparing healthy cells.
results_summary: Alpha-lactalbumin-oleic acid significantly reduced lesion volume by 75% or more in all treated patients during the first phase, with 83% achieving complete resolution at two-year follow-up. No adverse reactions were reported, and efficacy was consistent across immunocompetent and immunosuppressed patients.
population_specificity: 40 patients with cutaneous papillomas resistant to conventional treatment.
effective_dosage: Daily topical application (specific concentration not stated).
study_duration: 3 weeks per phase (initial blinded phase + open-label phase).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to develop a biosensor assay to determine the denaturation index of alpha-lactalbumin in milk by quantifying its native and heat-denatured forms.
results_summary: The study successfully developed a discriminating, fast, repeatable, and fully automated biosensor assay for measuring alpha-lactalbumin denaturation, independent of its original concentration in raw milk. The technique requires no pretreatment of milk samples.
population_specificity: Not specified (milk samples analyzed, not human subjects).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate whether in silico studies on anti-obesity peptides, including bovine alpha-lactalbumin, predicted effects consistent with subsequent in vitro and in vivo evaluations.
results_summary: The abstract does not provide specific findings on Alpha-Lactalbumin's effects, only noting its inclusion among anti-obesity peptides studied.
population_specificity: Not specified in the abstract.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether HAMLET (a complex of alpha-lactalbumin and oleic acid) could selectively induce apoptosis in glioblastoma tumors and prolong survival in a xenograft model.
results_summary: HAMLET reduced tumor volume, delayed pressure symptoms, and induced apoptosis in tumor cells without affecting adjacent healthy tissue or causing toxic side effects. After 8 weeks, HAMLET-treated rats remained asymptomatic, while control-treated rats developed pressure symptoms.
population_specificity: Nude rats (Han:rnu/rnu Rowett) with human glioblastoma xenografts.
effective_dosage: Not specified (administered via intracerebral convection-enhanced delivery for 24 hours).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the nutritional and immunomodulatory effects of bovine colostrum, including its Alpha-Lactalbumin content, compared to human breast milk and its potential benefits across different age groups.
results_summary: The study found that bovine colostrum contains immunoactive components like immunoglobulins and cytokines but differs from human breast milk, particularly in protein composition (casein vs. whey proteins like Alpha-Lactalbumin). It highlighted the need for further clinical research to validate its use, especially in preterm infants.
population_specificity: Preterm infants, neonates, adolescents, adults, and the elderly.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate how α-lactalbumin enhances the intestinal bioavailability of Myo-Inositol (MI) in the context of PCOS and insulin resistance.
results_summary: The study found that α-lactalbumin significantly improves the intestinal bioavailability of MI, overcoming previous limitations. This enhancement supports the use of MI in PCOS, though its effects on different PCOS phenotypes remain unclear.
population_specificity: Patients with polycystic ovary syndrome (PCOS) and insulin resistance, as well as those with type II diabetes and gestational diabetes mellitus (GDM).

study_goal: The abstract does not specifically mention Alpha-Lactalbumin, so the study goal regarding it cannot be determined.
results_summary: The abstract does not provide results related to Alpha-Lactalbumin.
population_specificity: Not specified in the provided abstract.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to review the functional, biological, and therapeutic properties of whey-derived bioactives, including Alpha-Lactalbumin, and their potential applications in food, pharmaceutical, and nutraceutical products.
results_summary: The study highlights Alpha-Lactalbumin's multifunctional effects, including anticancer, antihypertensive, and antimicrobial properties, as well as its roles in emulsification, encapsulation, and metal-ion transportation. The underlying mechanisms remain unclear, but key structural elements like peptide bonds and sulfhydryl groups are implicated in triggering these functions.
population_specificity: Not specified (review article, not a clinical study)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to analyze the links between asthma and PCOS and evaluate the therapeutic role of myo-inositol in asthma patients.
results_summary: The abstract does not mention Alpha-Lactalbumin or its effects.
population_specificity: Asthmatic patients with potential overlap with polycystic ovary syndrome (PCOS).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to examine cross-reactivity and allergenicity of mammalian milk proteins, including Alpha-Lactalbumin, in patients with cow's milk allergy.
results_summary: The study found that Alpha-Lactalbumin is a major allergen in donkey's and mare's milk due to the low casein/whey protein ratio in equine milk, potentially causing severe allergic reactions in sensitive individuals.
population_specificity: Pediatric and adult populations with cow's milk allergy or selective mammalian milk allergies.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effects of a novel starting formula (potentially containing Alpha-Lactalbumin) on infant weight gain, body composition, safety, and tolerability up to 6 and 12 months.
results_summary: The abstract does not provide specific results regarding Alpha-Lactalbumin's effects, only mentioning a multicenter, randomized, blinded, controlled clinical trial design.
population_specificity: Infants up to 6 and 12 months of age.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to highlight the nutritional and therapeutic properties of donkey milk, including its high content of protective proteins like Alpha-Lactalbumin, and its potential as a functional food.
results_summary: Donkey milk is rich in Alpha-Lactalbumin and other protective proteins, demonstrating strong antioxidant, antibacterial, antiviral, antifungal, hypoglycemic, antiparasitic, and antitumor activity. It is considered beneficial for cardiac health due to its fatty-acid profile and essential fatty acids.
population_specificity: General human consumption, with potential benefits for children (though fat enrichment may be needed for adequate caloric intake).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to systematically review studies examining the effectiveness of milk-derived proteins, including Alpha-Lactalbumin, in treating head and neck cancer.
results_summary: The abstract indicates a systematic review of in vitro and in vivo studies, suggesting potential anticancer effects of milk-derived proteins, but specific findings on Alpha-Lactalbumin are not detailed.
population_specificity: Head and neck cancer (in vitro and in vivo studies).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess the long-term effects of an α-lactalbumin-enriched infant formula on growth measures in children up to seven years of age.
results_summary: The study found no significant differences in anthropometric measures (weight, height, head circumference, body fat) between children fed the α-lactalbumin-enriched formula, control formula, or breastfed group by age seven.
population_specificity: Healthy term infants.
study_duration: Follow-up until seven years of age.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to explore the potential applications of Alpha-Lactalbumin (α-LA) in managing polycystic ovary syndrome (PCOS), particularly its effects on intestinal dysbiosis, insulin resistance, obesity, inflammation, and mental well-being.
results_summary: The study suggests that α-LA improves intestinal absorption of inositols, mitigates dysbiosis, and enhances insulin resistance and inflammation in PCOS. It also highlights α-LA's role in maintaining serotonin levels, potentially benefiting mental well-being and offspring health in women with PCOS.
population_specificity: Women with polycystic ovary syndrome (PCOS).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to review the potential presence, formation, and bioactive effects of the cytotoxic α-lactalbumin-oleic acid complex (HAMLET) in human milk, particularly for preterm infants.
results_summary: The study found that HAMLET, a complex of alpha-lactalbumin and oleic acid, exhibits specific toxicity to carcinogenic and immature cells, triggering apoptosis and inflammation via NF-κB and MAPK p38 pathways. The implications of these effects on immature intestinal tissues in preterm infants remain unknown.
population_specificity: Critically ill and very preterm infants dependent on human milk.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the safety and efficacy of a peptide-based molecular approach using alpha-lactalbumin-derived alpha1-oleate for targeting and killing tumor cells in non-muscle invasive bladder cancer.
results_summary: The study found that intra-vesical instillations of alpha1-oleate reduced tumor size and triggered massive shedding of tumor cells without drug-related side effects. Treated tumors showed apoptosis and inhibited expression of cancer-related genes.
population_specificity: Patients with non-muscle invasive bladder cancer.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the efficacy of alpha-lactalbumin in improving the effectiveness of inositol-based therapies for PCOS and infertility.
results_summary: The study found that alpha-lactalbumin enhanced the efficacy of inositol treatments, particularly in PCOS and infertility cases, by optimizing the myo-inositol/D-chiro-inositol ratio (40:1).
population_specificity: Women with Polycystic Ovary Syndrome (PCOS) and individuals with infertility (male and female).

study_goal: The abstract does not specify a study goal related to Alpha-Lactalbumin.
results_summary: The abstract does not provide results specific to Alpha-Lactalbumin.
population_specificity: Not specified in the abstract.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to review the biological potential and medical applications of milk and colostrum proteins, including Alpha-Lactalbumin, focusing on their antibacterial, antifungal, antiviral, anticancer, antioxidant, and immunomodulatory properties.
results_summary: The study highlights that Alpha-Lactalbumin, as part of milk and colostrum proteins, exhibits various beneficial properties, including antibacterial, antifungal, antiviral, and immunomodulatory effects, and is used in dermatological treatments and dietary supplementation.
population_specificity: Not specified (general review of milk and colostrum proteins across species like cows, goats, and sheep).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine if myo-inositol plus α-lactalbumin could reduce insulin resistance and excessive fetal growth in women with gestational diabetes mellitus.
results_summary: The study found that the combination significantly reduced insulin resistance (HOMA-IR) and fetal growth (abdominal circumference centiles) compared to the control group. It also decreased the need for insulin and preterm birth rates.
population_specificity: 120 women with gestational diabetes mellitus.
effective_dosage: Not specified (combined with myo-inositol and folic acid).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the potential of alpha-lactalbumin to enhance inositol absorption in the context of PCOS treatment.
results_summary: The abstract suggests that alpha-lactalbumin may improve inositol absorption, particularly in cases where impaired intestinal transport could otherwise lead to unsuccessful treatment. However, specific efficacy data or clinical outcomes related to alpha-lactalbumin are not detailed.
population_specificity: Women with polycystic ovary syndrome (PCOS) seeking pregnancy.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the effects of alpha-lipoic acid supplementation and electrical isotonic contraction on anthropometric parameters, body composition, and angiogenesis factors in obese individuals under a weight loss regime.
results_summary: The study evaluated the combined effects of alpha-lipoic acid and Faradic electrical isotonic contraction on obesity-related parameters, but specific results regarding Alpha-Lactalbumin were not detailed in the abstract.
population_specificity: Obese individuals meeting inclusion criteria.
effective_dosage: 600 mg alpha-lipoic acid (supplementation) and three 1-hour Faradic sessions per week.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the efficacy of a treatment combining Myo-inositol, melatonin, vitamin D3, and Alpha-Lactalbumin in improving clinical pregnancy rates and oocyte/blastocyst quality in women undergoing ICSI.
results_summary: The treatment significantly improved blastocyst and oocyte quality in the study group, achieving a 42% clinical pregnancy rate compared to 24% in the control group, though gestational period did not differ significantly.
population_specificity: Women undergoing intra cytoplasmatic sperm injection (ICSI).
effective_dosage: 50 mg Alpha-Lactalbumin (alpha-LA) daily in combination with other supplements.
study_duration: 6 months (3 months before oocyte pick-up and 3 months after ICSI).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the antioxidant activity of whey proteins, including Alpha-Lactalbumin, and their potential to modulate redox biomarkers to reduce oxidative stress.
results_summary: The study found that whey proteins, including Alpha-Lactalbumin, exhibit antioxidant activity and can modulate redox biomarkers, reducing oxidative stress in humans and animals. This effect has been partially attributed to whey peptides.
population_specificity: Humans and animals (not further specified)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the reliability of the Basophil Activation Test (BAT) for diagnosing IgE-mediated cow's milk allergy, including reactions to Alpha-Lactalbumin, compared to the gold standard DBPCFC.
results_summary: The BAT showed 100% sensitivity and specificity in IgE-sensitized children for diagnosing cow's milk allergy, including reactions to Alpha-Lactalbumin. Non-IgE-sensitized children with mild symptoms had negative BAT results, suggesting non-IgE-mediated mechanisms.
population_specificity: 86 infants/young children suspected of (persistent) cow's milk allergy.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to quantify and compare the temporal changes of major proteins, including alpha-lactalbumin, in preterm and term human milk over postpartum periods.
results_summary: Alpha-lactalbumin decreased with advancing lactation in both preterm and term human milk, with significantly lower levels in preterm milk during 39-48 postmenstrual weeks, suggesting limited availability for preterm infants after reaching term corrected age.
population_specificity: Preterm (gestational age 28 0/7-32 6/7 weeks) and term (gestational age 37 0/7-41 6/7 weeks) infants.
study_duration: 4 months for preterm, 2 months for term human milk collection

study_goal: The researchers aimed to identify predictive cut-off values for specific IgE and Skin Prick Tests in diagnosing cow's milk allergy, including Alpha-Lactalbumin, in pediatric patients.
results_summary: The study found that none of the proposed cut-offs definitively confirm cow's milk allergy diagnosis, but in children under 2 years, specific IgE or SPT cut-offs were more consistent and potentially useful.
population_specificity: Pediatric patients, particularly children under 2 years.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine how different dietary proteins, including Alpha-Lactalbumin-enriched whey protein, affect postprandial metabolomic changes after a high-fat meal.
results_summary: The study found that Alpha-Lactalbumin-enriched whey protein (LAC) led to a moderate increase in urinary acylcarnitines and other acylated metabolites related to fatty acid oxidation compared to casein (CAS), though less pronounced than whey protein (WHE). The type of protein significantly influenced postprandial fatty acid oxidation pathways.
population_specificity: 10 healthy overweight men with elevated waist circumference (>94 cm)
effective_dosage: 15% of total energy intake from protein (LAC, WHE, or CAS)
study_duration: 3-period crossover study with postprandial measurements up to 6 hours

study_goal: The researchers aimed to establish cutoff points for serum-specific IgE and skin reactivity to predict clinical reactivity to cow's milk, including its fractions like Alpha-Lactalbumin.
results_summary: The study found that Alpha-Lactalbumin-specific IgE levels and skin papule diameters were significantly higher in allergic patients, with cutoff points of 0.95kUA/L for serum IgE and 6.5mm for papule diameter to predict reactivity.
population_specificity: 122 children (median age 17 months) with a history of immediate reactions to cow's milk and presence of specific IgE for cow's milk or its fractions.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to review the therapeutic potential and mechanisms of HAMLET (Alpha-Lactalbumin complex) in targeting tumor cells and its efficacy in cancer treatment.
results_summary: HAMLET demonstrated broad tumoricidal effects, specificity for cancer cells, and therapeutic efficacy in animal models of glioblastoma, bladder cancer, and intestinal cancer, as well as clinical targeting of skin papillomas and bladder cancers. The mechanism involves membrane integration, ion flux activation, internalization, and inhibition of key cellular pathways.
population_specificity: Tumor cells (in vitro and animal models) and human patients with skin papillomas and bladder cancers.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the potential of Alpha-Lactalbumin in immunotherapy for milk whey protein allergies, focusing on identifying dominant epitopes.
results_summary: The study found that synthetic β-lactoglobulin peptides were effective in reducing skin symptoms in mice sensitized to milk whey proteins, but no dominant epitopes were identified in Alpha-Lactalbumin, limiting its therapeutic potential.
population_specificity: Mice sensitized to milk whey proteins.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine how the quality of formula protein, specifically an increased α-lactalbumin content, affects the energetic efficiency of infant formula compared to breast milk.
results_summary: The study found that improved protein quality, including increased α-lactalbumin content, increased the energetic efficiency of infant formula by about 13%, contributing to better growth and metabolism similar to breast-fed infants.
population_specificity: Apparently healthy, term, fully formula-fed infants with normal weight.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine if inducing immunity against 'retired' self-proteins like Alpha-Lactalbumin could provide prophylactic protection against aggressive breast cancer.
results_summary: The study proposes that targeting 'retired' self-proteins, such as Alpha-Lactalbumin, may offer a viable strategy for immunoprevention of age-related cancers like breast cancer, with ongoing clinical trials testing this approach.
population_specificity: Healthy cancer-free subjects, with a focus on preventing aggressive breast cancer.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the extent of protein degradation, including Alpha-Lactalbumin, in infant gastric samples and whether bioactive peptides are released.
results_summary: The study found that Alpha-Lactalbumin-derived peptides were significantly more abundant in gastric samples than in milk, suggesting active digestion in infants. Many identified peptides, including those from Alpha-Lactalbumin, exhibited previously known biologic activity, such as immunomodulatory and antibacterial properties.
population_specificity: Human mothers and their 4- to 12-day-old postpartum infants.
study_duration: Not specified (analysis focused on samples collected within the first 2 weeks postpartum).

study_goal: The researchers sought to summarize current evidence on the role of Alpha-Lactalbumin (α-LA) in H. pylori eradication as a complementary therapy.
results_summary: The study found that evidence for α-LA in H. pylori eradication is promising, though the magnitude of benefit is small and clinical settings are ill-defined. Further research is needed to determine optimal use.
population_specificity: Patients with H. pylori-related conditions (peptic ulcer disease, chronic gastritis, gastric adenocarcinoma, mucosa-associated lymphoid tissue lymphoma).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to explore the potential of milk proteins and peptides, including Alpha-Lactalbumin (HAMLET), as multi-functional agents with anti-cancer, immunomodulatory, and other therapeutic effects.
results_summary: The study highlights that milk-derived biologics like HAMLET show promising results in clinical trials, demonstrating anti-cancer, anti-metastasis, and immunomodulatory effects. These proteins and peptides are well-tolerated and may complement standard cancer therapies.
population_specificity: Not specified (general cancer-related research).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether yoghurt enriched with alpha-lactalbumin and other bioactive components could reduce stress more effectively than standard yoghurt in high-trait anxiety individuals.
results_summary: The study found that the enriched yoghurt group showed higher vigor, reduced feelings of inefficiency, and improved heart rate variability and recovery index compared to the control group. These results suggest that bioactive-enriched yoghurt may aid in stress coping.
population_specificity: High-trait anxiety individuals aged 18-63 years (n=67).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the discriminatory concentration of Alpha-Lactalbumin-specific IgE for diagnosing cow's milk allergy in children.
results_summary: The study identified a cut-off point of 2.06 kU/L for Alpha-Lactalbumin-specific IgE with 98% specificity, contributing to CMA diagnosis without requiring component testing. The ROC curve analysis indicated strong discriminatory capacity for whole cow's milk over individual components.
population_specificity: Children (median age 1.91 years) with CMA diagnosis via DBPCFC, anaphylaxis, or clinical history and positive skin prick test.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to explore the potential benefits and considerations of adding bovine Alpha-Lactalbumin to infant formula to mimic human milk's bioactive properties.
results_summary: The abstract suggests that Alpha-Lactalbumin, among other milk proteins, may contribute to infant health and development, but its efficacy depends on digestibility and amino acid composition. The study highlights the need for careful protein content adjustment in formulas to match breastfed infants' serum amino acid levels.
population_specificity: Infants (formula-fed compared to breastfed)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess the effect of a modified infant formula containing Alpha-Lactalbumin (ALAB) and LC-PUFA on infant growth compared to a standard formula.
results_summary: The modified formula with ALAB and LC-PUFA showed higher length gain and improved energetic efficiency for growth compared to the control formula, despite lower protein content. Both formulas were well-accepted with no significant health-related differences.
population_specificity: Healthy term infants from the first month of life until 120 days of age.
effective_dosage: 1.89 g protein/100 kcal (containing ALAB and LC-PUFA).
study_duration: From the first month of life until 120 days of age.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to review the anti-inflammatory properties of milk proteins, including Alpha-Lactalbumin, and their potential role in preventing or treating intestinal inflammation in infants and children.
results_summary: The study highlights Alpha-Lactalbumin as one of several whey proteins with anti-inflammatory effects, supported by in vitro and in vivo studies, suggesting its potential utility in managing gut inflammation.
population_specificity: Newborn infants, particularly growth-restricted or premature infants at risk of necrotizing enterocolitis (NEC).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to review clinical trials involving milk-derived proteins and peptides, particularly Alpha-Lactalbumin (LA), to assess their safety and efficacy in health-promoting applications, including infant and adult formulae and cancer treatment (HAMLET).
results_summary: The study found that Alpha-Lactalbumin, often used with glycomacropeptide (GMP), is applied in health-promoting infant and adult formulae and in a modified form (HAMLET) for cancer treatment. The abstract suggests that milk-derived products, including LA, are safe and effective in preventing and treating infections, autoimmune diseases, and neoplastic conditions.
population_specificity: Infants, adults, and cancer patients (specific to HAMLET application).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the potential anti-cancer effects of whey protein subfractions, including Alpha-Lactalbumin, and their role in mitigating cancer cachexia syndrome.
results_summary: The study found that whey protein subfractions, including Alpha-Lactalbumin, exhibit specific anti-cancer effects in vitro and in vivo, but clinical effects are indiscernible. Whey protein supplementation may help mitigate cancer cachexia due to its leucine content and potential to modulate IGF-1 concentrations.
population_specificity: Not specified (general oncology context).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to examine the relationship between breastfeeding (and its components like alpha-lactalbumin) and reduced breast cancer risk, focusing on potential mechanisms such as HAMLET-induced tumor cell apoptosis.
results_summary: The study suggests that breastfeeding reduces breast cancer risk through breast tissue differentiation and fewer ovulatory cycles, with alpha-lactalbumin (as part of HAMLET) inducing tumor-specific apoptosis. HAMLET was effective against tumor cells while sparing normal cells.
population_specificity: Women with a history of breastfeeding (general population focus).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the tumoricidal activity of Alpha-Lactalbumin (HAMLET) and its potential as a novel cancer therapy.
results_summary: HAMLET demonstrated broad tumoricidal activity by targeting conserved death pathways in tumor cells, with therapeutic effects shown in human skin papillomas, bladder cancers, and glioblastomas, without toxicity to normal tissues.
population_specificity: Human tumor cells and tissues (skin papillomas, bladder cancers, glioblastomas).

study_goal: The researchers evaluated the efficacy of topical treatments, including alpha-lactalbumin-oleic acid, for cutaneous non-genital warts in healthy, immunocompetent adults and children.
results_summary: The study found no advantage of topical alpha-lactalbumin-oleic acid over placebo in treating warts. The evidence for its efficacy was insufficient or inconclusive.
population_specificity: Healthy, immunocompetent adults and children with cutaneous non-genital warts.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess the tolerability of Parmigiano-Reggiano (PR) containing Alpha-Lactalbumin (ALA) in cow's milk allergic children and characterize its biochemical and immunological properties.
results_summary: The study found that 58% of cow's milk allergic patients tolerated fully maturated PR, with IgE binding to milk allergens largely inhibited by PR preparations. ALA showed minimal loss of allergenic reactivity during digestion compared to caseins.
population_specificity: Seventy children with suspected cow's milk allergy.
effective_dosage: Not specified (open food challenge with 36-month-maturated PR).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine if sensitization to endogenous human milk proteins, particularly Alpha-Lactalbumin, could explain persistent allergic symptoms in breastfed infants with cow's milk allergy despite maternal dietary milk avoidance.
results_summary: The study found that IgE antibodies from 60% of milk-allergic infants recognized human milk peptides, including Alpha-Lactalbumin, with functional IgE detected in infants unresponsive to maternal diet changes. Autoreactive IgE to human milk proteins may contribute to persistent symptoms, but their clinical role remains unclear.
population_specificity: Breastfed infants (3 weeks to 12 months) and older children (5-15 years) with cow's milk allergy.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the acute effect of Alpha-Lactalbumin on postprandial lipaemia compared to other milk-derived proteins.
results_summary: The study found no significant differences in postprandial triglyceride levels between Alpha-Lactalbumin and the other proteins. Alpha-Lactalbumin did not show unique effects on secondary metabolic markers.
population_specificity: 11 obese non-diabetic subjects (age 44-74, BMI 30-41.4 kg/m²).
effective_dosage: 45 g of pure protein per high-fat meal.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to explore the biological activities of Alpha-Lactalbumin, including its role as a source of tryptophan and its digestion into bioactive peptides with antimicrobial, prebiotic, immunostimulatory, and mineral absorption-enhancing effects.
results_summary: The study found that Alpha-Lactalbumin is digested into smaller peptides with multiple beneficial activities, including antimicrobial and prebiotic effects, immunostimulation, and enhanced mineral absorption. No adverse effects were mentioned, but further clinical studies on infants are needed.
population_specificity: Not specified (general potential application in infant formulas).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to summarize the structural, functional, and therapeutic properties of protein complexes with oleic acid, specifically HAMLET and ELOA, and their antitumor activities.
results_summary: HAMLET and ELOA exhibit potent tumoricidal activity, with HAMLET showing strong potential as an antitumor drug in animal models and clinical studies. The complexes are formed via partial protein unfolding and fatty acid binding, which enhances their dynamic and functional properties.
population_specificity: Not specified (in vitro, animal models, and clinical studies referenced).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to discuss the potential of tumoricidal proteins, including HAMLET (human α-lactalbumin made lethal to tumor cells), in inducing tumor-selective death as part of cancer therapy strategies.
results_summary: The abstract highlights HAMLET as a tumoricidal protein capable of selectively targeting and killing tumor cells, emphasizing its potential in cancer therapy. It is presented as part of broader strategies to induce tumor-selective death, alongside other proteins and pathways.
population_specificity: Not specified (general discussion of cancer therapy concepts).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to describe the prevalence, immunological basis, diagnostic methods, and treatment options for cow's milk protein allergy (CMPA), including reactions to Alpha-Lactalbumin.
results_summary: The abstract highlights that CMPA is an immunological reaction to milk proteins like Alpha-Lactalbumin, with symptoms varying by IgE or non-IgE mechanisms. Treatment involves dietary elimination and specialized formulas, but no specific efficacy or safety data for Alpha-Lactalbumin is provided.
population_specificity: Children with cow's milk protein allergy (CMPA).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the association between dietary alpha-linolenic acid (ALA) intake and body fat indices in healthy Iranian adults.
results_summary: Higher dietary ALA intake was significantly associated with lower body fat mass, percentage of body fat, visceral fat area, and waist-to-hip ratio in men. The study suggests ALA may be a preventive treatment for improving body composition.
population_specificity: Healthy Iranian adults aged 20 to 60 years.
effective_dosage: Mean daily intake was 0.18 ± 0.18 mg/day for men and 0.17 ± 0.19 mg/day for women.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the anti-epileptic and neuroprotective effects of Alpha-Linolenic Acid (ALA) and explore its potential mechanisms in a chronic epilepsy mouse model.
results_summary: ALA significantly reduced epileptic seizure frequency, improved behavioral and cognitive impairments, decreased neuron apoptosis, and lowered brain inflammatory factors (IL-6, IL-1, TNF-α). The study suggested ALA's mechanism involves down-regulating the JAK2/STAT3 pathway.
population_specificity: Mice exposed to pentylenetetrazol (PTZ)-induced seizures.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the causal relationship between reduced ALA levels and nephritis risk, as well as the potential benefits of ALA supplementation in nephritis treatment.
results_summary: Reduced ALA levels due to lipid-lowering drugs were linked to increased risk of acute tubulointerstitial nephritis (ATIN) and tubulointerstitial nephritis (TIN). The study suggests ALA supplementation may enhance the efficacy of existing lipid-lowering drug regimens for nephritis treatment.
population_specificity: Patients with nephritis, including IgA nephropathy and lupus nephritis.
interactions: Lipid-lowering drugs (reduced ALA levels linked to increased nephritis risk)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to explore the effects of ALA on obesity-induced adipose tissue accumulation, cognitive impairment, inflammation, and colonic mucosal barrier integrity.
results_summary: ALA treatment prevented high-fat diet-induced adipose tissue accumulation, improved glucose and lipid metabolism, reduced inflammation, enhanced cognitive function, and protected colon and liver health. It also inhibited adipocyte differentiation and induced ferroptosis.
population_specificity: Mice fed a high-fat diet.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the role of Alpha-Linolenic Acid (ALA) in modulating host responses to Singapore grouper iridovirus (SGIV) infection and its potential antiviral effects.
results_summary: The study found that SGIV infection led to a significant down-regulation of ALA and other lipid metabolites, disrupting lipid homeostasis. ALA suppressed SGIV replication by activating antioxidant and anti-inflammatory responses, highlighting its antiviral potential.
population_specificity: Groupers (fish) infected with Singapore grouper iridovirus (SGIV).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the effects of dietary hempseed or camelina cakes on the fatty acid profiles, particularly Alpha-Linolenic Acid (ALA), in quail meat.
results_summary: Camelina cake supplementation significantly increased ALA content in quail meat by 2.5 times, along with other beneficial n-3 PUFAs. Hempseed cake also increased ALA but to a lesser extent and had a negative impact on growth performance.
population_specificity: One-day-old quail (189 birds) divided into three dietary treatment groups.
effective_dosage: 10% replacement of rapeseed cake with hempseed or camelina cake in the diet.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to review the roles of ALA in addressing metabolic-related dementia, focusing on its effects on insulin resistance, dyslipidemia, synaptic plasticity, cognitive function, and neuropsychiatric issues.
results_summary: The study suggests that ALA plays a significant role in regulating cellular mechanisms like apoptosis, inflammation, mitochondrial biogenesis, and insulin signaling, and its inadequate intake is linked to neuropathology and metabolic imbalances. The review highlights ALA's potential for concurrent treatment of metabolic syndrome and neurological problems.
population_specificity: Not specified (general review of existing literature)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether Alpha-Linolenic Acid (ALA) could alleviate Toxoplasma gondii-induced colitis by modulating gut microbiota and suppressing pro-inflammatory cytokines via the MyD88/NF-κB pathway.
results_summary: ALA reduced pro-inflammatory cytokine expression, inhibited the MyD88/NF-κB pathway, mitigated colitis, and improved host survival. It also reshaped beneficial gut bacteria colonization, such as Lactobacillus and Enterococcus.
population_specificity: Mouse models infected with Toxoplasma gondii cysts.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the effects of dietary alpha-linolenic acid (ALA) and linoleic acid (LA) on lipoprotein(a) [Lp(a)] and other atherogenic lipids, and to examine whether FADS1 rs174550 genotype modifies these responses.
results_summary: ALA lowered serum Lp(a) by 7.3% and reduced LDL cholesterol, non-HDL-C, remnant-C, and apolipoprotein B more effectively than LA. Both diets showed greater absolute decreases in individuals with higher baseline Lp(a), but FADS1 genotype did not influence responses.
population_specificity: 118 men homozygous for FADS1 rs174550 SNP (TT or CC).
effective_dosage: 30-50 mL/day of Camelina sativa oil (ALA diet) or sunflower oil (LA diet), adjusted by BMI.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess the effects of dietary camelina oil (a source of ALA) on health parameters and plasma lipid profiles in horses, comparing it to canola and flax oils.
results_summary: The study found no adverse effects on health parameters from camelina oil supplementation. Plasma ALA levels were higher with flax oil than canola oil, but camelina oil showed intermediate effects. Both camelina and flax oils reduced the n-6:n-3 ratio over time.
population_specificity: Thirty horses from three separate herds (mean age 14.9 years, mean weight 544 kg).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether Alpha-Linolenic Acid (ALA) could protect against methotrexate (MTX)-induced nephrotoxicity in mice by reducing oxidative stress, inflammation, and apoptosis.
results_summary: ALA significantly reduced oxidative stress, inflammatory mediators, and apoptotic markers induced by MTX. Histopathological findings showed ALA attenuated renal tissue damage caused by MTX.
population_specificity: Mice (animal study)
effective_dosage: 200 mg/kg ALA administered once daily by gavage

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether Penaeus vannamei shrimp can synthesize EPA and DHA from exogenous ALA and how this process affects their immune response.
results_summary: The study found that exogenous ALA or Vibrio parahaemolyticus challenge modulated EPA and DHA levels and immune gene expression in shrimp by inducing key enzymes in n-3 PUFA biosynthesis. Knockdown of ∆6 desaturase significantly reduced EPA and DHA levels and immune gene expression, impairing antibacterial immunity and survival.
population_specificity: Penaeus vannamei (Pacific whiteleg shrimp)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the anti-cancer activity of ALA in oral squamous cell carcinoma (OSCC), specifically its mechanisms in inhibiting metastasis and inducing apoptotic cell death.
results_summary: ALA reduced cell growth in a concentration-dependent manner, with low concentrations inhibiting migration, invasion, and EMT-related proteins, and high concentrations activating apoptotic pathways. ALA demonstrated potential as a treatment for OSCC by suppressing metastasis and promoting cell death.
population_specificity: Oral squamous cell carcinoma (OSCC) cells (SAS and GNM cell lines).
effective_dosage: Low concentrations (100 or 200 μM), high concentrations (200 or 400 μM).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the effects of camelina oil (high in ALA) with flaxseed and canola oil on skin and coat health in horses.
results_summary: All oil supplements improved coat color and quality in horses, with no significant differences between camelina, flaxseed, or canola oil. Camelina oil was found to be comparable to other plant-based oils in supporting skin and coat health.
population_specificity: Adult horses (23 mares, 7 geldings; mean age 14.9 years, mean weight 544 kg).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effectiveness of ALA-appended nanostructured lipid carriers (NLCs) for targeted delivery of docetaxel (DTX) to glioblastoma (GB) cells, overcoming the blood-brain barrier (BBB) and chemoresistance.
results_summary: ALA-DTX-NLCs demonstrated enhanced permeation through an in-vitro BBB model, higher uptake in patient-derived GB cells, and 13.9-fold higher DTX activity compared to bare DTX-NLCs, showing better efficacy than GLA-DTX-NLCs in 3D tumor spheroids and patient-derived cells.
population_specificity: Glioblastoma (GB) cells, including immortalized and patient-derived cells.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the effects of ALA supplementation on cardiovascular disease (CVD) risk factors in overweight or obese individuals.
results_summary: ALA supplementation significantly reduced C-reactive protein, tumor necrosis factor-α, triglycerides, and systolic blood pressure but increased low-density lipoprotein cholesterol. No significant effects were observed on interleukin-6, diastolic blood pressure, total cholesterol, or high-density lipoprotein cholesterol.
population_specificity: Adults with obesity or overweight.
effective_dosage: ≥3 g/d from flaxseed and flaxseed oil.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate factors influencing the conversion of ALA into long-chain metabolites and its effect on cardiovascular risk markers.
results_summary: ALA, C-20:4n3, and EPA concentrations increased in erythrocytes, while docosahexaenoic acid and n-3 index decreased in most groups. Conversion to EPA was higher in men and those with low baseline EPA status, but high LA intake attenuated conversion rates. No clear effects on blood lipids or glucose metabolism were observed.
population_specificity: 105 subjects (57.4 ± 12.1 years; 65.7% female) completing the study.
effective_dosage: 10 en% linseed oil (22-27 mL ≙ 13-16 g ALA).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to analyze the effects of Alpha-Linolenic Acid (ALA) on cardiovascular health and investigate the optimal omega-6/omega-3 ratio for beneficial outcomes.
results_summary: ALA demonstrated favorable effects on LDL-C and triglyceride levels in both adult and pediatric populations, as well as protective effects against hypertension and potential cardiovascular disease risk reduction through anti-hypertensive, anti-atherosclerotic, and cardioprotective mechanisms.
population_specificity: Adult and pediatric populations

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the impact of low-ratio linoleic acid/alpha-linolenic acid (LA/ALA) supplementation on blood lipid profiles in adults.
results_summary: Low-ratio LA/ALA supplementation significantly reduced total cholesterol (TC), low-density lipoprotein cholesterol (LDL-C), and triglycerides (TG), but had no effect on high-density lipoprotein cholesterol (HDL-C). The effects were more pronounced with intervention periods under 12 weeks and LA/ALA ratios of 1-5.
population_specificity: Adults
study_duration: Varied, with notable effects under 12 weeks

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate changes in whole-blood PUFA levels, including ALA, in children with severe acute malnutrition (SAM) after treatment with different RUTF formulations.
results_summary: The study found that ALA levels were lower in the L-RUTF group compared to the S-RUTF group at discharge, with no significant improvement in PUFA status overall. No associations were found between ALA and health markers like inflammation or hemoglobin status.
population_specificity: 121 Cambodian children aged 6-59 months with severe acute malnutrition.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate whether Alpha-Linolenic Acid (ALA) could serve as a broad-spectrum antiviral therapy against respiratory infections, including SARS-CoV-2 and RSV.
results_summary: ALA demonstrated antiviral potential by degrading viral particles, reducing viral plaque formation, and modulating cytokine expression in infected cells. In mice, ALA-liposome treatment reduced viral load and lung inflammation.
population_specificity: Calu-3 cells, A549 cells, and mice infected with murine-adapted SARS-CoV-2 (MA10).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to review the effects of dietary fatty acids, including Alpha-Linolenic Acid (ALA), on activating brown adipose tissue (BAT) and remodeling white adipose tissue (WAT) to beige fat.
results_summary: The study found that ALA, among other fatty acids, may activate BAT and promote WAT remodeling to beige fat, potentially aiding in energy dissipation and combating obesity. The mechanisms and effects of ALA were summarized, though specific efficacy data were not detailed.
population_specificity: Not specified (review of existing literature)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate whether Alpha-Linolenic Acid (ALA) metabolism is a key pathway through which Acanthopanax senticosus (ASH) impacts Parkinson's disease (PD).
results_summary: The study found that ASH intervention influenced ALA metabolism, which may be linked to improved motor function in PD model mice. ALA was identified as part of key metabolic pathways, including unsaturated fatty acid synthesis, suggesting its role in ASH's therapeutic effects.
population_specificity: α-syn transgenic mice (PD model) and C57BL/6 mice (control).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to review the health benefits of flaxseed oil, particularly its ALA content, and its potential therapeutic effects on various diseases.
results_summary: The study found that flaxseed oil, rich in ALA, exhibits multiple health benefits, including antioxidant, anti-inflammatory, antimicrobial, anticancer, and cardioprotective effects, with mechanisms linked to its phytochemical composition.
population_specificity: Not specified (general human health focus).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether Alpha-Linolenic Acid (ALA) could inhibit Zika virus (ZIKV) infection and its potential as a broad-spectrum antiviral agent.
results_summary: ALA inhibited ZIKV infection by disrupting viral binding, adsorption, and entry stages, likely by compromising virion membrane integrity. It also showed dose-dependent inhibition against DENV-2, HSV-1, influenza virus, and SARS-CoV-2.
population_specificity: In vitro cell culture (specific human population not specified).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess the health impact of different LA levels and LA/ALA ratios in infant formula, focusing on safety, biological effects, and DHA synthesis.
results_summary: The study found that LA/ALA ratios closer to 5:1 promote higher endogenous DHA synthesis, but even optimal ratios do not match breastfed infants' DHA levels. Current evidence suggests no benefit to exceeding the maximum LA level of 28% FA in infant formula.
population_specificity: Infants consuming infant formula, with additional data from breast milk samples across 31 countries.
effective_dosage: Not specified (focus on ratios: 5:1 to 15:1 LA/ALA).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the effects of Alpha-Linolenic Acid (ALA) on testosterone biosynthesis and the underlying signaling pathway in primary rooster Leydig cells.
results_summary: ALA significantly increased testosterone secretion, with an optimal dose of 40 μmol/L, and upregulated the expression of steroidogenic enzymes (StAR, P450scc, 3β-HSD) via the JNK-SF-1 signaling pathway. Inhibitors of JNK, ERK, and p38 reversed these effects, indicating their role in ALA-mediated testosterone biosynthesis.
population_specificity: Primary rooster Leydig cells

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether plasma levels of ALA and other PUFAs could predict survival time and functional decline in patients with ALS.
results_summary: Higher ALA levels were associated with lower risk of death and slower functional decline in ALS patients, suggesting a favorable effect on disease progression. Similar associations were observed for other PUFAs like eicosapentaenoic acid and linoleic acid.
population_specificity: 449 participants with ALS (mean age 57.5 years, 65.3% male) from the EMPOWER clinical trial.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate changes in nutrient intake, including Alpha-Linolenic Acid (ALA), following bariatric surgery and its correlation with anthropometric and metabolic outcomes.
results_summary: The study found a significant decrease in ALA intake post-surgery (0.87% to 0.69% of energy intake). ALA's effects were not directly assessed, but reduced intake correlated with metabolic and anthropometric changes.
population_specificity: Patients who underwent bariatric surgery (LRYGB, LSG, or LAGB).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effects of omega-3 PUFAs, including ALA, on blood pressure regulation and cardiovascular outcomes, focusing on their vascular mechanisms.
results_summary: The study suggests that omega-3 PUFAs, including ALA, have beneficial effects on blood pressure regulation in both hypertensive and normotensive subjects, mediated by vascular tone modulation. However, early intervention trials showed inconsistent results regarding cardiovascular risk reduction.
population_specificity: Hypertensive and normotensive subjects (not further specified).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether Alpha-Linolenic Acid (ALA) enhances GABAergic neurotransmission in hyperexcitable brain regions (BLA and CA1) and explore its potential as a treatment for neuropsychiatric disorders.
results_summary: A single dose of ALA significantly increased GABAergic inhibitory activity in the BLA (52%) and CA1 (92%) compared to controls, an effect mediated by BDNF signaling, as blocking TrkB abolished the improvement.
population_specificity: Animal models (rats/mice, not specified) with hyperexcitable brain regions.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the therapeutic effect and mechanism of Alpha-Linolenic Acid (ALA) in an ovalbumin-induced allergic rhinitis (AR) mouse model.
results_summary: ALA reduced nasal symptoms, inflammation, IgE levels, and Th2-cell responses while improving epithelial barrier function by modulating the IL-4Rα-JAK2-STAT3 pathway.
population_specificity: Ovalbumin-sensitized AR mouse model.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the nutritional and health benefits of dietary omega-3 PUFA, specifically ALA and DHA, on laying hens' immune responses under LPS challenge.
